skill.name: qutip
skill.description: Quantum physics simulation library for open quantum systems. Use when studying master equations, Lindblad dynamics, decoherence, quantum optics, or cavity QED. Best for physics research, open system dynamics, and educational simulations. NOT for circuit-based quantum computing—use qiskit, cirq, or pennylane for quantum algorithms and hardware execution.
skill.summary: Quantum physics simulation library for open quantum systems. Use when studying master equations, Lin...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing markdown files with QuTiP code examples. ALL 397 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES caused by the analyzer misinterpreting documentation syntax. No executable code, network calls, file system access, or external commands exist in this skill.

content.value_statement: QuTiP enables simulation of open quantum systems including master equations, Lindblad dynamics, and decoherence. Use it for quantum optics research, cavity QED experiments, and educational demonstrations of quantum phenomena.
actual_capabilities: Create and manipulate quantum states (Fock, coherent, thermal) and operators (Pauli, annihilation, angular momentum)
Solve time evolution for closed systems (sesolve) and open systems with dissipation (mesolve, mcsolve)
Compute expectation values, entropy measures (von Neumann), concurrence, fidelity, and correlation functions
Visualize quantum states on the Bloch sphere, Wigner functions, Q-functions, and Fock distributions
limitations: Does not support circuit-based quantum computing (use Qiskit, Cirq, or PennyLane for quantum algorithms)
Does not provide quantum gate compilation or transpilation for hardware execution
Hilbert space dimension scales exponentially; large systems require careful truncation strategies
Performance depends on solver choice; inappropriate solver selection may cause slow simulations

use_cases.title: Open quantum system dynamics
use_cases.description: Study decoherence, dissipation, and relaxation in quantum systems using master equations and collapse operators.

use_cases.title: Cavity QED simulations
use_cases.description: Model light-matter interactions including Jaynes-Cummings dynamics, photon statistics, and field evolution.

use_cases.title: Quantum mechanics education
use_cases.description: Create visualizations of quantum states on the Bloch sphere to teach superposition and measurement concepts.

prompt_templates.title: Basic quantum state
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create a qubit in the |+⟩ state using QuTiP and visualize it on the Bloch sphere.

prompt_templates.title: Open system evolution
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me simulate a qubit undergoing spontaneous emission using the master equation solver in QuTiP. Include the Hamiltonian, collapse operator, and plot the expectation value of sigma_z over time.

prompt_templates.title: Wigner function analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Calculate and plot the Wigner function for a coherent state with amplitude alpha=2 in a 10-level system using QuTiP. Show the negative values that indicate non-classical behavior.

prompt_templates.title: Jaynes-Cummings model
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up a Jaynes-Cummings model in QuTiP for a cavity coupled to a two-level atom. Include the Hamiltonian in the rotating wave approximation, dissipation for both cavity and atom, and plot the time evolution of photon number and atomic excitation.

output_examples.input: Show me how to simulate energy relaxation in a qubit
output: Setup: Define the qubit Hamiltonian (H = ω·σz/2) and collapse operator (σ- with decay rate γ)
Initial state: Prepare the qubit in the excited state |1⟩
Time evolution: Use mesolve() to solve the master equation with the collapse operator
Analysis: Extract expectation values of σz over time to observe T1 relaxation behavior
Result: Expect exponential decay from ⟨σz⟩ = 1 to ⟨σz⟩ = -1 with time constant T1 = 1/γ

best_practices: Choose the appropriate solver: sesolve for pure unitary evolution, mesolve for open systems with dissipation
Truncate Hilbert spaces to the minimum dimension needed to capture the relevant physics
Use string-based time-dependence format (e.g., 'cos(w*t)') for better performance with time-dependent Hamiltonians
anti_patterns: Using mcsolve for simple expectation values (mesolve is more efficient for ensemble averages)
Forgetting to include collapse operators when simulating open quantum systems (results will be wrong)
Using overly large Hilbert space dimensions without justification (causes unnecessary memory usage)

faq.question: What is the difference between sesolve and mesolve?
faq.answer: sesolve solves the Schrödinger equation for pure states (unitary evolution). mesolve solves the master equation for mixed states with dissipation.

faq.question: How do I choose the Hilbert space dimension N?
faq.answer: Start small and increase until results converge. For a harmonic oscillator, truncate where occupation probabilities become negligible.

faq.question: Can QuTiP simulate circuit model quantum computers?
faq.answer: No. Use Qiskit, Cirq, or PennyLane for circuit-based quantum computing. QuTiP is for continuous-variable and open system dynamics.

faq.question: What are collapse operators in open quantum systems?
faq.answer: Collapse operators describe system-bath interactions that cause dissipation, decoherence, or measurement backaction in open quantum systems.

faq.question: How do I visualize quantum states on the Bloch sphere?
faq.answer: Use the Bloch class: create a Bloch() object, add states with add_states(), and display with show() or save with save().

faq.question: What is the difference between Wigner and Q-functions?
faq.answer: The Wigner function can have negative values (indicating non-classicality). The Q-function is always positive but provides less quantum information.
